title: How often do publishing companies accept books? - Quora

response.answer_text: As often as they publish them. So look at a publisher’s list for a given month, count the new (non-reprint) titles, and that’s how many books they accepted in a month. I don’t have any recent numbers handy but I remember that when I sold my first novel in 1979 Del Rey Books published six titles a month, of which at least two and sometimes as many as four were reprints. Let’s say it averaged out to three per month. That means Del Rey (as of 1979) bought thirty-six books a year, or one every ten days. Meanwhile, they received several hundred submissions a month. The number of submissions has skyrocketed since then — back then you needed to use a typewriter and street mail, there were no word processors yet (unless you count ROFF, which I don’t), and computer printers were big clumsy things that only printed in dot matrix. My understanding is that every publisher receives thousands of submissions per month now — but they still only buy enough to fill their publishing schedule.

I don’t know that there’s a solid statistic. They accept books they feel they can successfully publish, that meet professional standards and generally meet a specific need in the market (or that they believe will create one). Most books are rejected. I would hesitate to try to put a better number on it than that.
